About Today: Protection of the Theotokos. This special Feast Day of the Byzantine Church is celebrated every year since A.D. 911 when the Theotokos miraculously appeared in the Church of Blachernae in Constantinople. — St. Ananias, Apostle, one of the 70, who baptized St. Paul, the Apostle. — Our venerable father, Roman, the sweet-singer, author of many Kondaks, about A.D. 496.

St. Cyprian, Priest-Martyr, a cultured Carthaginian, was converted and consecrated Bishop of Carthage. He wrote much and was a cordial friend of the Martyr Pope, St. Cornelius. He won his crown of Martyrdom by beheading A.D. 258 under the Emperor Valerian. — St. Justina, Virgin-Martyr, beheaded at Nicomedia under Emperor Diocletian, A.D. 300. — St. Andreas, who became "a fool for Christ's sake."
Remarks: Simple abstinence from meat or equivalent penance.

About Today: St. Denis, the Areopagite, Priest-Martyr, first Bishop of Athens, converted by St. Paul, the Apostle, and with him Rusticus and Eleutherius, Athenian converts (Acts 17:34).

St. Hierotheus, Priest-Martyr, Bishop of Athens, disciple of St. Paul. Tradition has it that he was translated on a cloud to Jerusalem to be present at the Dormition of the Theotokos. — Venerable St. Francis of Assisi.
Remarks: Franciscan Usage. St. Francis of Assisi, Gal 5:22-6:2; Mt 11:27-30.

About Today: St. Charitina, Martyr, suffered Martyrdom A.D. at Amasa on the Black Sea, under Emperor Diocletian.
St. Thomas, the glorious Apostle, otherwise called Didymus (twin). He is stated to have preached the Gospel in Parthia, in Media and in India, where he is said to have suffered martyrdom.
SS. Sergius and Bacchus, Martyrs, were officers in the Imperial Army and were put to death A.D. 296 during the reign of Maximian, Emperor.
Our venerable mother, Pelagia, Public sinner, but later penitent in a cave on Mt. Olivet near Jerusalem. Pelagia died A.D. 457.

St. James the Lesser, son of Alpheus, Apostle and Brother of St. Matthew, the Apostle and Evangelist. — Our venerable father, Andronicus and his wife, Athanasia, from Antioch of Syria. On the death of their children they agreed to separate and thenceforth led lives of prayer and penance in the solitude of Upper-Egypt.
Remarks: Simple abstinence from meat or equivalent penance.

About Today: SS. Eulampius and his sister, Eulampia, Martyrs at Nicomedia A.D. 302 under the reign of Maximian Herculeus. They were young children, who for their Faith were cast into a cauldron of boiling oil but miraculously came out unhurt, and thereupon were beheaded. Two hundred soldiers witnessing this became converts and were put to death as Christians.

Day Name: SUNDAY OF THE FATHERS OF THE 7TH ECUMENICAL COUNCIL
About Today: St. Phillip, one of Seven Deacons, converted the Samaritans, baptized the eunuch of Candace, Queen of Ethiopia (Acts 8), and was the host of St. Paul at Caesarea (Acts 21:8). His four daughters are honored as Saints with him. He became Bishop of Tralles in Lydia, and there suffered martyrdom. — Our venerable father, Theophan, Confessor, Bishop of Nicea and composer of Canons, opposed the Iconoclasts at the 2nd Council of Nicea (A.D. 787). Banished by Emperor Leo the Armenian, he died in exile A.D. 818.
Remarks: Feast of John XXIII, Pope of Rome.

About Today: SS. Probus, Tarachus and Andronicus, Martyrs, suffered martyrdom during the reign of Diocletian A.D. 292. — Our venerable father, Cosmas, Bishop of Majuma, composer of Canons.
SS. Carpus, Bishop of the Church in Thyatira, and Papylus, his Deacon, and with them Agathonica, sister of Papylus, and Agathodorus, their servant, suffered A.D. 250 in the persecution under Nero.

Our venerable mother, Paraskevia, child of peasant parents, of the city of Callicratia. Her relics were translated to Trapezont, a city in Bulgaria, A.D. 1201. — SS. Nazarius, Gervase, Protase and Celsus, Martyrs. St. Nazarius' father was a heathen, his mother, Perpetua, a Christian, probably a disciple of St. Peter. At Milan with his companion, Celsus, he was beheaded under Emperor Nero about A.D. 60. Gervase and Portase were brothers, sons of the St. Vitalis, Martyr. Their relics repose in Milan in the Ambrosian Basilica.

Our venerable father, Euthymius, the New. — St. Lucian, Venerable-Martyr, Presbyter of greater Antioch, was put to death for the Faith at Nicomedia in Asia Minor by order of Emperors Maximian and Galerius, buried at Helenopolis in Bithynia.
Remarks: Carmelites, Our Venerable Mother Theresa of Avila.

About Today: St. Longinus, the Centurion, is credited by tradition to have been the one who pierced the side of Our Lord hanging on the Cross (John 19:34). Converted to Christianity, he was put to death in Cappadocia. His body is venerated in the Church of St. Augustine in Rome.
Remarks: Simple abstinence from meat or equivalent penance.

About Today: St. Hosea, Prophet, a descendant of Isachar, lived in the 8th century B.C. — St. Andrew of Crete, Venerable-Martyr opposed the Iconoclasts and reproached the Emperor Constantine for his impiety. The enraged monarch ordered him to be seized and tortured, from which he died A.D. 761.

St. Luke, Apostle and Evangelist, was a physician of Antioch in Syria, converted to Christianity, became the fellow-worker of St. Paul. He is the inspired writer of the Third Gospel and of the Acts of the Apostles, as revealed to the Prophet Ezekiel in the vision on a calf, six centuries B.C.
Remarks: Feast of the Holy Apostle Luke, Epistle, Col 4:5-9,14-15 & 18; Gospel, Lk 10:16-22.

About Today: St. Joel, Prophet, was of the Tribe of Ruben in the 8th century B.C. — St. Varus, Martyr, a Roman soldier, who while guarding some condemned monks in prison for their Faith, on seeing one of them expire in his dungeon, took his place and shared the torture and cruel death of the others A.D. 307. — St. Sadoth, Priest-Martyr, a Bishop in Persia, who, with 128 of his fellow Christians, was put to death A.D. 345 by King Sapor near Ctesiphon.
St. Artemis, Great Martyr, a veteran officer in high command was charged with breaking down the statue of an idol. After cruel torture he was beheaded A.D. 363 under the Apostate, Emperor Julian.
Our venerable father, Hilary the Great, Hegumen-Abbot. After a long life of severe fasting and prayer, and having founded many monasteries in Palestine, died at age of 80 in Cyprus A.D. 371.
St. Abercius, Equal to the Apostles, Bishop of Hieropolis, wonderworker, died about A.D. 167. — SS. Seven Youths of Ephesus. (Confer August 4.)
Remarks: Feast of John Paul II, Pope of Rome.

About Today: St. James, Apostle, brother of the Lord, the first Bishop of Jerusalem. He composed the First Liturgy which was later abbreviated somewhat by St. Basil the Great and still more by St. John Chrysostom. At 96 years of age he suffered martyrdom at the hands of the Jews, who cast him down from the pinnacle of the Temple A.D. 61. — Our holy father, Ignatius, Confessor, was the son of the Byzantine Emperor Michael. Successively he was monk, Hegumen-Abbot, Presbyter and became Patriarch of Constantinople A.D. 842. After 9 years of exile he died at age 80 A.D. 878.
Remarks: Simple abstinence from meat or equivalent penance.

About Today: SS. Arethas and other Martyrs with him, endured death A.D. 523.
SS. Marcian and Martyrius, Martyrs. Marcian, a Lector and Martyrius, a Sub-deacon, in Constantinople were put to death A.D. 351.
St. and Glorious Demetrius, the Great, Myrrh-exuding Martyr, martyred A.D. 299. Many miracles have taken place at his shrine at Thessalonica.
St. Nestor, Martyr, endured death A.D. 304. — S.S. Captiolina, a Cappadocian lady, with her handmaid, Erotheides, Martyrs, suffered death A.D. 304 under Emperor Diocletian.

St. Paraskevia, Martyr, surnamed "Friday," who endured death at Iconium A.D. 290. — SS. Terentius and Neonila and their children: Photius, Anicetas, Theodulus, Hierarchus and Eunicius. — Our venerable father, Stephen of Sabbas, composer of Canons about A.D. 785.

St. Anastasia, Venerable-Martyr from Rome is said to have been a nun of the community presided over by St. Sophia. She was brought before Probus during the persecution of Valerian, Emperor, and undergoing the most frightful tortures and outrages was beheaded A.D. 253. — SS. Abram, Hermit of Edessa and Mary, his niece, died about A.D. 360.

SS. Zenobius and Zenobia, his sister, Martyrs, suffered death A.D. 304. — Venerable, Peter, Bishop of Syracuse, disciple of St. Peter, Apostle. — SS. Asterius, Claudius, Neon, Theonilla, Martyrs, A.D. 285 at Aegea in Silicia under the reign of Diocletian, Emperor. — SS. Terentius, Mark, Justus and Artem, Apostles, four of the Seventy Apostles.
Remarks: Simple abstinence from meat or equivalent penance.

About Today: SS. Stachis, Ampliatus, Urban and Narcissus, Apostles, mentioned by St. Paul the Apostle in his Epistle to the Romans (16:8-9 & 11) — St. Epimachus, Martyr, of Alexandria in Egypt, was burned there at the stake, A.D. 250 in the Decian persecution. — Our venerable mother, Maura.
